## Building the input channel

::: {style="font-size: smaller"}
ðŸ”§ Input is read from a CSV in `main.nf`:

``` nextflow
Channel
  .fromPath(params.input)
  .splitCsv(header: true)
  .map { row ->
      def meta = [id: row.sample, org: row.org]
      def reads = file(row.fastq, checkIfExists: true)
      [meta, reads]
  }
```
:::

## Building the input channel

::: {style="font-size: smaller"}
ðŸ”§ Input is read from a CSV in `main.nf`:

``` nextflow
Channel
  .fromPath(params.input)
  .splitCsv(header: true)
  .map { row ->
      def meta = [id: row.sample, org: row.org]
      def reads = file(row.fastq, checkIfExists: true)
      [meta, reads]
  }
```

-   `[meta, reads]` is a channel of pairs (tuples): `meta` is a map (`[id: 'human_1', org: 'human']`) and `reads` is a FASTQ file.
-   Keeps metadata and data together as they flow through the pipeline.
-   `id` and `org` are accessed as `meta.id` and `meta.org`
:::

:::

## Task 4: taming the data stream

::: incremental
::: {style="font-size: smaller"}
-   **Channel structure from `EXTRACT_SEQUENCE.out.sequence`:** `[meta, seq]` â†’ `meta` is a map that includes the `id` and `org` fields.

-   **Goal:** Group all sequences by `org` â†’ Required for computing GC content per group.

-   **Step 1 â€“ Map to `[org, seq]`:**

    ``` nextflow
    .map { meta, seq -> [meta.org, seq] }
    ```

    â†’ Makes the org easy to access for grouping.

-   **Step 2 â€“ Group by `org`, now the first element (index 0) of each item:**

    ``` nextflow
    .groupTuple(by: [0])
    ```

    â†’ Groups sequences under the same id, resulting in a channel of grouped tuples: \[org, \[seq1, seq2, ...\]\]
:::
:::

## Common headaches

-   Config hierarchies! You can convince yourself of this by messing around with where you set your `params.reverse_complement`... ![](Lecture_files/imgs/param%20hierarchy.png){fig-align="center"}

## Common headaches

-   Q: Why does only one sample run through the pipeline instead of all of them? A: Queue channels (e.g sample reads) vs. value channels (eg. genome reference).
-   If you print (with `println`) a channel variable and itâ€™s a value channel, regardless of its content it will always show `DataflowVariable(value=null)`. A queue channel on the other hand will print `DataflowBroadcast around DataflowStream[?]`.
